fields.description:
This morning I came in and our bamboo instance seemed hung (couldn't connect to the web UI).  We were very low on disk space with a number of concurrent builds running.  Yesterday I had setup a number of new build queues and they worked well throughout the day.

Not knowing what to do, I did a 'bamboo.sh stop'.  When I brought the server back up, it was missing the configuration changes I had made to generate the new build queues.  In addition, we were on build-200 something of a particular project, it reverted to build-135.  It seems like the database doesn't get checkpointed, so if you don't shutdown gracefully you lose your settings and build/test info - is this accurate?

I'm going to try to switch to MySQL if i can.
fields.summary: Bamboo locked up and lost my configuration changes

fields.description: Build expiry should be enabled on a per-project basis.  This allows us to expire artifacts for continuous builds more frequently than for release builds.
fields.summary: build expiry should be availalbe on a per project basis

fields.description:
When the Jira plugin for Bamboo is enabled, if the Bamboo server goes down there are long delays when switching between tabs on a Jira issue. (By tabs I mean the links for "All", "Comments", "Change History", "P4 Jobs" and "Related Builds" on the Jira issue.)

The Jira log shows a timeout of about 30 seconds, which I think is what Jira is waiting for. It might be neat to have the plugin do a little 'ping check' kind of thing before it tries to connect for real so we don't get these huge delays when our admittedly unreliable Bamboo server stops responding.

Thanks!


-mattyj
fields.summary: Jira/Bamboo connection locks up when Jira connection to Bamboo is lost

fields.description:
I think a really useful feature would be to have markers in the " Build Duration & Number of Failures per Build" diagram, that mark at which time 25% of the successfull builds were reached, at which time 50% were reached, etc.

This would give some Information about whether success was primarily in the distant past or near the present.

Otherwise I have to count the total number of successfull builds, calculate the percentages and habe to count from the beginning to find out something about the temporal distribution of failed builds.

I would do it myself if I had access to the source.
fields.summary: DIagram: Distribution of the "Mass" of successfull builds over time.

fields.description:
The expected element type of the List returned by implementations of BuildResult.getBuildLog() and accepted by BuildResult.setBuildLog(List) is undocumented.

At least one plugin assumes that the element type is the SimpleLogEntry class (see BAM-1375), when I believe the intention is that be the LogEntry interface.

We should document this before too many third party plugins make the same mistake.

Also, we should check our own implementations of this interface.
fields.summary: Type of build log entries is undocumented in Javadoc

fields.description: The Build Labeller plugin is assuming that the List returned by BuildResults.getBuildLog() contains instances of the SimpleLogEntry class, rather than of the LogEntry class, which I think is the intention behind the interface contract (which we  should explicitly document - expect another JIRA issue).
fields.summary: Labeller plugin assumes that build log contains instances of SimpleLogEntry rather than LogEntry

fields.description:
h2. Bamboo double-builds if a change is made while a build is waiting to run

We have two builds that share a queue.  Each build is about 20-30 minutes long.  The following scenario occurs frequently:
a) Build A starts
b) Build B gets triggered by change #2 in SVN and becomes enqueued
c) change #3 happens in SVN
d) Build A finishes, Build B starts - it does an SVN update so it has both change #2 and change #3
e) Build B finishes, runs again and indicates its now building the change #3 stuff which was already build at step (d)

Since our builds are long, and our queues are shared, this can slow down things.  It'd be great if it could recognize the difference between a build being enqueued and actually running and properly combine the triggers events such that they are combined into a single build request...
fields.summary: Add an ability to force an update to HEAD before a build is executed

fields.description:
it would be very nice to be able to have multiple builds within the same plan. For instance, we have a build which happens on every check in. but we also have a weekly build that runs database scripts, and another which is run to generate junit reports across all builds.

in the above three plans in the same project you need to have three complete checkouts of the project. (and we maintain something like 30 projects!)

This would also be a workaround for another issue we have (BAM-904) in which we would like to have a separate builds of our trunk, and most recent branch. it would help it in this way:

project: trunk, 
    plan: proj1
    plan: proj2

project: branch,
    plan: proj1
    plan: proj2

In the first case. you could check out the trunk, and for the build, use a subdirecory of proj1, or proj2, etc. likewise for the branch. This will now work now, because we would end up with a build-dir that looked like:
TRUNK-PROJ1, TRUNK-PROJ2, each with complete checkouts. not good. It might be possible to create a symlink, all pointing to one directory, but that seems like it would be fragile.
fields.summary: the ability to have multiple builds within the same repository

fields.description:
We have a number of build queues.
One of these queues is set to accept all plans. This is necessary so that we don't accidentally end up with a plan that cannot be built.
Another queue is set to accept "fast builds", that is those builds which we know will be completed quickly. This, in theory, prevents the fast builds from being stuck behind a really slow build.

The problem we run into is if 3 builds are triggered at the same time. 1 Slow, 2 Fast.
The Slow build is assigned to the "all plans" queue.
The 1st of the fast builds is assigned to the "fast plans" queue.
The 2nd fast build then gets assigned to the "all plans" queue, and sits for an hour waiting for the slow build to complete.
The 1sto f the fast builds then completes, and the "Fast queue" sits idle, while the "all plans queue" has a backlog of entries.

Possible ways I could see this being fixed are:
# Don't assign a plan to a queue until the last possible minute. The plan would sit waiting for a queue to be available and would kick off as soon as an appropriate queue was empty.
# Allow us to create a queue which said "All plans except..." then we could still have our catch-all queue ready for new plans, but not allow our slow builds to run on it.
# When choosing a queue to which to add the plan, look at the estimated time remaining for the already queued builds.
fields.summary: Assigning of build to queues is non-optimal

fields.description:
Bamboo should store be able to associate a JIRA project with each build, along with a SOAP login for that JIRA instance. When an CVS/SVN commit is made, Bamboo should parse the comments. If the comments begin with a JIRA issue identifier such as BAM-123, then once the test has been completed, Bamboo will use the JIRA SOAP interface to perform an workflow transition or add comment operation on that issue. 

For example, when a user commits a bug fix with a reference to the JIRA issue of that bug in the commit comments, the bug gets closed automatically if the tests pass. Any text following the JIRA issue identifier will be posted as a comment to the issue.

| Commit Result | JIRA Issue State | JIRA WorkflowTransition | Operation |
| Pass | Open | Resolve Issue (Fixed) |  Add comment |
| Fail | Open | None | Add comment |
| Pass | Resolved | None | Add comment |
| Fail | Resolved | Reopen | Add comment |

Thoughts:
- This would need to deal with custom workflows, possibly by downloading the list of workflow operations and criteria to allow customisation. 
- How to populating required fields for transitions, eg from the comments?
- Optionally, you could associate the workflow operation or comment with the JIRA account of the committer, but this would require a mapping between CVS/SVN user accounts and JIRA user accounts
- This issue could be implemented as a Bamboo plugin
fields.summary: If a commit is associated with a JIRA issue, Bamboo modifies the issue state based on the test outcome

This was done to fix an issue with ' in javascript so we need to be smarter about where this fix is applied.
fields.summary: Single quotes in logs are prefixed with a back slash \

fields.description:
Clicking on the RSS link (in the URL field) on a plan's page should not throw a 404 error

Originally a support issue (See, [BSP-123|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-123])
fields.summary: Subscribing to a RSS feed from a plan page leads to a 404 page not found exception

fields.description:
We have a tree of projects. B depends on A.

If you checkin something to B that relies on a corresponding change to A, but the A change isn't correct, it is likely that you will cause a test failure in B.
Score is now -1. One break of B.

You then notice it and checkin a new fix for A. A is build and triggers a B build.
The rebuild of project B is labeled as a dependency build, and thus isn't counted as a "build fix".
fields.summary: Author score doesn't take into account dependent builds.

fields.description: If project B depends on project A, it would be nice to be able to place project B and its dependencies into a blocked state till A succeeds. We're using ivy for multi project building, and when the parent doesn't pass, it doesn't get published to the repository, so the child project won't see any new changes from the parent, usually leading to compile issues somewhere down stream.
fields.summary: Block dependant plans till parent succeeds

fields.description:
When a build is fixed, the "time to fix" is based on actual calendar time elapsed.

As a result, some builds may be broken for many hours or days (nights, weekends, holidays), while others are resolved in minutes - with equal effort.
This may lead to a false interpretation of the telemetry.

An improvement would be to support a configurable workday for a Project.  However, builds triggered outside of regular working hours would still reflect the default "absolute calendar time" behavior.
fields.summary: Time to fix should support configurable workday

fields.description:
Currently, comments on a build are treated as plain text.  Even URLs are not turned into clickable hyperlinks.

An ideal solution would render comments with basic wiki markup and URLs, just like JIRA does.
fields.summary: Support wiki markup in comments

fields.description:
Charles mentioned a build server that he used a long time ago (Continuum?) had a neat feature where the original committer who caused a build failure would be "on the hook" until the build passed. In addition, anyone who committed to a failing build and didn't make it pass (and therefore could have broken more stuff) would also be "on the hook" until the build passed. Once the build passes, everyone that is on the hook gets "let off the hook".

This notion seems useful, particularly for notifications. It would be great if IM notifications only went to people on the hook. The current notification scheme only allows committer notifications, which isn't as useful when there are multiple commits while the build is failing.

It would be also good to have a telemetry screen with mug-shots of those users who are "on the hook". This gives the team an idea of who is (or should be) fixing the build at the moment.

This could possibly be developed as a plugin; I'm not sure how customisable these things are in Bamboo. It's probably a matter of adding some new metadata to a failing build (a list of users who are on the hook), and exposing that for use by notification schemes.

If it can't be a plugin, I think it would be a useful addition to Bamboo core.
fields.summary: Users who commit to any failing build are "on the hook" until success

fields.description: It looks like the clover XML file is only being scanned and stats being added to Bamboo only if the build succeeds.  Would it be possible to always scan for the Clover output instead?  We have a lot of tests, and some of them can fail... it doesn't change the fact that clover is going to output some HTML & XML.

fields.summary: invalid instant messager testing

fields.description:
On the summary screen for a completed build result, you have a list of the 5 code changes, their authors and comments, and can click through to a detailed list of changes.

On the summary screen for a running build, you have a list of the code changes, with their authors and comments, but you can't click anywhere to get the detailed list of changes. (See attached screenshot.)

It would be great if you could link up the detailed code changes screen so you could see the detailed code changes for a build that isn't complete yet.
fields.summary: Detailed code changes screen can't be accessed from a running build

fields.description: Bamboo indexes a lot of data. In a high use installation, it's not uncommon for the indexes to be 10GB and takes > 12 hrs to reindex fully. While reindexing shouldn't really need to occur, we should look at ways to trim down the index and not lose the core functionality.
fields.summary: Indexes are slow to reindex

fields.description:
Please integrate OpenGrok for source browsing http://www.opensolaris.org/os/project/opengrok/

Currently simple reference to source code works fine, but it would be nice to have full support of this product: diff, version comparions etc.

Thanks,
Andrei
fields.summary: integrate with Opengrok VC browser

fields.description: Bamboo allows for "latest" links to everything from plan info to artifacts. We should make this more prominent
fields.summary: Add permanent  links to "latest" on the various Plan screens
System Variables in Bamboo should be able to reference themselves
An option to delete local working copy of the repository before building

fields.description:
Bamboo should have an option to run the build before committing it to source repository in case of failure Bamboo won't make commit to Source Repository.

See, http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257248405#257248405
fields.summary: If build fails - hold  off commit from Source Repository

fields.description:
when trying to conenct to the ldap server, atlassian-user.xml looking like

<atlassian-user>
        <repositories>
                <ldap key="ldapRepository" name="LDAP Repository@hecate.atlassian.com" cache="false">
                <host>sso.ops4j.org</host>
                <port>xxx</port>
                <securityPrincipal>uid=xxx,ou=xxx</securityPrincipal> ---------------taken out, they work
                <securityCredential>xxxt</securityCredential>
                <securityProtocol>plain</securityProtocol>
                <securityAuthentication>simple</securityAuthentication>
                <baseContext>dc=ops4j,dc=org</baseContext>
                <baseUserNamespace>dc=users,dc=ops4j,dc=org</baseUserNamespace>
                <baseGroupNamespace>dc=groups,dc=ops4j,dc=org</baseGroupNamespace>
                <usernameAttribute>uid</usernameAttribute>
                <userSearchFilter>(objectClass=inetOrgPerson)</userSearchFilter>
                <firstnameAttribute>givenname</firstnameAttribute>
                <surnameAttribute>sn</surnameAttribute>
                <emailAttribute>mail</emailAttribute>
                <groupnameAttribute>cn</groupnameAttribute>
                <groupSearchFilter>(objectClass=groupOfUniqueNames)</groupSearchFilter>
                <membershipAttribute>uniquemember</membershipAttribute>
                </ldap>
                <hibernate name="Hibernate Repository" key="hibernateRepository" description="Hibernate Repository"/>
                </repositories>
                </atlassian-user>

which is working in my confluence 2.4.5 instance, I get somthing like this:

Internal server error

Thank you!

fields.description:
With more complex projects it is often useful to be able to specify multiple check-outs for a build.

For example, what we do at my work place is:

$ cvs co -r infrastructure_1_1 eng/infrastructure
$ cvs co eng/applications

But depending on what you're doing, you might also do:

$ cvs co -r infrastructure_newest eng/infrastructure
$ cvs co eng/applications

So it would be nice to be able to specify different branches for different check outs.  You can't express this with a CVS module because modules can't mix and match branch specifications.
fields.summary: allow multiple modules and branches to be checked out in a single plan

fields.description:
When I visit this page:

http://keg.sydney.atlassian.com:8080/bamboo/build/admin/edit/defaultBuildNotification.action?buildKey=CONF-NIGHTLY&lastModified=11763713

The title is " - Bamboo".
fields.summary: Edit build notification screen has no title

fields.description:
Currently, variables in Bamboo have limited scope and are applicable only to specific plans. 

The user should be able to specify global variables - applicable globally in Bamboo.

See http://forums.atlassian.com/post!reply.jspa?messageID=257248320.

{quote}
Has anyone been able to get the bamboo global variables to expand properly in the "System Environment Variables:" section of a builder? The global variables expand properly in the "target" section, but so far I have been unable to use them anywhere else. Are Bamboo global variables only usable in the "target" or "argument" section of a builder, or am I missing something?

It would be very useful if Bamboo global variables could be used anywhere, including when defining builder paths and jdk home directories in the Admin UI.
{quote}
fields.summary: Ability to specify (global) System Variables to be global in Bamboo

fields.description:
I logged out from bamboo and tried to log in for administration, I get "Internal error, sorry our apologies" and the web page asks me to repost the issue here.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Internal server error

fields.description:
We would like to be able to see in the summary of a manual build who it was run by.

example:
# Ran: 8 minutes ago
# Manual build invoked by John Doe
# Duration: 7 minutes
# Tests: 1 passed 

also who ran the manual build and when should appear in a log somewhere.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Ability to see who executed a manual build

fields.description:
Make a depot view that has no specific view into the repository, e.g.

View:
    //depot/...     //client-view/...

Trying to add such view to the plan configuration will cause "Could not work out where perforce will check out the source code."

If the view had a view name, e.g. "//depot/... //client-view/source/.." it would work.
fields.summary: Perforce depot access will fail if the depot contains no workspace mapping

fields.description: Javascript is cached so that you only ever download it once per version of Bamboo. This is fine, but the size of certain downloads can still be pretty heavily optmised to minimise that initial hit
fields.summary: Large initial javascript download

fields.description:
Improve Notification Framework - so that users can write plugins to integrate with other IM services (Skype, MSN etc)

See, http://forums.atlassian.com/post!reply.jspa?messageID=257248200
fields.summary: Improve the Notification Framework in Bamboo, to register listeners

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to see what / who triggered a build.  This especially applies to dependency builds - to know which parent triggered the particular build.

This was asked for as part of a request for better notifications i imagine it could be useful elsewhere.
fields.summary: Keep track of what/who triggered a build

fields.description: This means if you are building something which has a dependency on the path, it probably won't work

fields.description: Sometimes, when the number of tests changes, I want to understand the differences between the tests in two different builds. Perhaps you could show this in the interface, but I could do it myself if there was a way to get a complete list of the tests for a build.
fields.summary: Show a list of all successful tests run for a build

fields.description: The indexes can get bloated rather quickly... Need a mechanism to automatically re-optimise the index
fields.summary: Bamboo needs to automatically optmise its indexes

fields.description:
Similarly but differently to BAM-839, I am getting odd interpretation of html displayed in Bamboo error reports.

All special html characters are being displayed as a single ampersand, when displayed by an assertion failed error

Eg 
{noformat}
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Unexpected text 'Results ' found in response '&!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd"&
&html&
&head&
            &title&Site Search - Confluence&/title&
{noformat}

instead of 

{noformat}
Unexpected text 'Results ' found in response '<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html>
<head>
             <title>Site Search - Confluence</title>
{noformat}
fields.summary: Bizarre HTML escaping

fields.description: Currently you have the functionality to use regular expressions to exclude directories from kicking off a build, but it only allows one line to enter the regular expression in.  We have about 10 directories that we exclude from kicking off builds.  It would make it a lot easier to maintain if we could enter in a regular expression for each directory one at a time.  Similar to the functionality you have added for notifications.

fields.description:
We are evaluating the bamboo for continues integration support. We have configured our build script to generate xml test reports in project directory. The build are working fine and the reports are getting generated. Is it possible to send these junit reports attached with daily build report.

Thanks,
Anshaj
fields.summary: Can bamboo send xml reports generated by junit with build email alert

fields.description:
I can't seem to set multple environment variables for a build. The following works

TEST=mytestvalue

In my ant build.xml ....

<property environment="env" />
<echo>${env.TEST}</echo>

Works fine. When setting multiple ....

OTHERTEST=myothertestvalue TEST=mytestvalue

Ant echoes '${env.TEST}' literally.
fields.summary: Can't set multiple build environment variables

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo can only build off the trunk of the repository. Bamboo should be able to perform one-off build from tagged version of a project 

Originally a forum post (See, http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257247884#257247884)

{quote}
Hi all,

This is no doubt a perversion of Bamboo's intended use, but what
would be really useful for us would be the ability to create a one-
off build based on a tagged version of a project.

Here's the ideal setup:

1. Create a project ('FOO').
2. Create a plan ('BAR') which points at the SVN trunk for the project:
http://svn.myserver.com/svn/foo/bar/trunk
3. Elsewhere, create a tag of the 'BAR' project (eg. '1.0').
http://svn.myserver.com/svn/foo/bar/tags/1.0
4. Back in Bamboo, I click the new 'Tags' tab in the Plan UI. It
automatically lists all tags for the project, and will allow me to
run the current build with the same settings as the current Plan,
except that it's pointing at the tag instead of the trunk. All
standard Bamboo events will occur, including generation of artifacts,
etc.
{quote}
fields.summary: Bamboo and tagged releases -  ability to do one-off builds from a specific tag in the repository.

fields.description:
We have updated Bamboo from version 1.0.2 to 1.1.1. Now I've noticed, that I can't expand a project with 2 plans (with a new User), or a known user (with an expanded view) can't fold the project with the +/- Buttons. Exeption is the first project.

Originally discussed in the forum. See http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257247836#257247836
fields.summary: Can't expand/collapse a project with many plans

As discussed in forum http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257247868#257247868
